author: davidhq
content:
SMS is the wrong idea, I think .... I'm personally using the approach of having a `push notification` app directly installed on my iphone through my developer program.

Input here is very welcome, what would be the best way for the other side of this problem, I think we can iterate very quickly in releasing this.

author: davidhq
content:
This approach of being completely independent with no middlemen, `push notications` between me and my phone OS provider might not be for everyone (you need a developer account and installing the app directly not through the app store)... So maybe then the correct way would be to release this simple `notifier` app through my developer account and share it with others? I think it can be free forever since apple does not charge for notifications....          Not sure how to do it for Android...

If anyone has better ideas for this push part, just write .... I'd rather not have to maintain a notifier app since it also needs a server component... Was looking for useful, free and reliable third party solutions, didn't find any.

author: davidhq
content: I've been working with small computers (RPi and others) for two years with a lightweight process running on each one of them and they all are sending push notifications on interesting events... so yes, this is awesome and should be part of anyone's arsenal.. you want to be notified in realtime if your important services have issues.

author: davidhq
content:
Here is the code for iPhone notification receiver https://github.com/dmtsys/ios-notify -- anyone with developer account can install it on the phone, it will show a device token... this is to be plugged into long running process on your server which also monitors eth2 clients and then stuff will work.

So, please write if interested in moving this forward... we have a lot of ingredients to make it happen but needs some more thinking / work.

author: pietjepuk
content: <@!375471494081282048> slashers don't advertise themselves, but you can safely assume that there is at least one person out there running a slasher

author: pietjepuk
content: lighthouse slashers are selfish by default though (in a good sense I feel), so they'll only include slashings in their own proposed blocks

author: pietjepuk
content: I forget if current slashers can catch _every_ slashable offense, but certainly the most likely ones

author: mohseng
content: can you please explain this part?  I am running a slasher but on Prysm.  Are they different on the amount they make?

author: pietjepuk
content: I am not sure about the default behavior of Prysm's slasher. I think they used to be selfish by default. Poking <@!311971895828283393>

author: raulj
content: Our slasher broadcasts by default to the network

author: raulj
content: We are rewriting our slasher close to end of the year, and we can reconsider this behavior

author: mohseng
content: Thanks. So what's the difference if it broadcasts to the network or is selfish?  I guess what does it mean being selfish?  I thought they have to broadcast and that's how a validator gets slashed... <@!311971895828283393>

author: jgm
content: Selfish seems detrimental to the network.  If there really is an attack going on it helps the network to know about it ASAP and shut down the relevant validators rather than dribbling out slashings over a period of days or weeks.

author: djrtwo
content: selfish might be marginally profit maximizing for an individual, but I expect there to be at least a few non-selfish broadcast slashers that would likely make a selfish strategy moot

author: djrtwo
content: (I run one of these.)

author: mohseng
content: thanks.

content: well, then the specs should reward the whistleblowers üòâ

author: raulj
content: Yep Jim nailed it. Imagine that you caught a bunch of slashings but youre not proposing a block until perhaps two weeks from now

author: raulj
content: you are withholding that valuable data from the network

author: raulj
content: the whistleblower reward, for just finding one slashing, is not really that big. Slashings should also (hopefully) be rare
